name: 3,5-bis(trifluoromethyl)phenylacetic acid
Reason: 3,5-Bis(trifluoromethyl)phenylacetic acid has a melting point that we will compare to benzene, which has a melting point of 5°C. The trifluoromethyl functional group introduces a significant dipole moment, increasing intermolecular forces and melting point by approximately +50°C. The phenyl group contributes to an increase in molecular weight and van der Waals interactions, with an approximate increase of +20°C. The carboxylic acid group introduces a hydrogen bonding potential, raising the melting point by approximately +10°C. The trifluoromethyl group also introduces a significant increase in molecular weight and van der Waals interactions, with an approximate increase of +20°C. The presence of two trifluoromethyl groups can be estimated to increase the melting point by approximately +40°C due to the additional rigid structure and dipole moment.
